title: If F(x) =x^2 - 3 and G(x) = 3 - x, what’s (F•G) (4)? - Quora

response.answer_text: F(G(x)) = F ( G(x) ) = (G(x))^2 - 3 { all we did is substituted G(x) for x in F(x) } = [ 3 -x]^2 - 3 { all we did is put what G(x) is } = 9 - 6x + x^2 -3 = 6 - 6x + x^2 = x^2 - 6x + 6 So F(G(4)) = 4^2 - 6(4) + 6 = 16 - 24 + 6 = -2
-2 I believe. You plug the 4 into G, which gives you -1. Then you plug that into F. (-1)^2 - 3 = 1 - 3 = -2
Multiply each term of f by each term of g, and combine like terms, terms and then solve for x = 4
